author: Aurélien
message:
@Nick: I had a look at the applications you suggested but they do not fit my needs:
- tudu: Web-based
- tdl: No keywords, home-made database format, no multi-line task description
- yagtd: Use a text file, which can lead to corruption if started multiple times (I used it before starting yokadi), no multi-line task description
-ditz: Interesting project, didn't know it, but it's more centered around bug-tracking imho.

Thanks for notifying me about the broken link!

author: Moult
message:
I have always used DevTodo as my CLI todo list application. It's fast, colour highlighting, sane priority choices (out of 5, not out of 9), and it's directory based (if you're in a different dir, it's a different list). This makes it really useful for programming projects, for example you can have a separate list for each module.

http://swapoff.org/DevTodo

I would not appreciate another clone, unless there is something that really makes this one better.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: @Moult: DevTodo looks like an interesting project, but it lacks a few features from Yokadi, for example there is no keyword support, due date, or bug tracking facilities.

author: Moult
message:
Ah well, keyword support is now what I'm looking for, nor a due date as many of my todo's can span across several years.

Whatever works, I guess.

author: Aurélien
message:
@Moult: I guess you mean "not what I'm looking for" :-)

To avoid any confusion, due date is not mandatory, you can set it when it's relevant. But I agree with you, "whatever works".
